facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 297 of 1956 filed by special leave against judgment and order dated August 30, 1955 of Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 220 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 297 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 30, 1955, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta in Appeal No. Cal. 220 of 1954.

facts.text: Appellants are workmen of Dimakuchi tea estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before us are the workmen of the Dimakuchi tea estate represented by the Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha, Dibrugarh. The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang in Assam.

facts.text: Respondent is management of Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang, Assam.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the management of the Dimakuchi tea estate, district Darrang in Assam. One Dr. K. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950.

facts.text: Dr. K. Banerjee appointed assistant medical officer of Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

anchor.surface_text: One Dr. K. Banerjee was appointed assistant medical officer of the Dimakuchi tea estate with effect from November 1, 1950. He was appointed subject to a satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

facts.text: Appointment letter stated that during probation suitability for permanent employment would be considered, 7 days notice if unsuitable, instant dismissal for misconduct, confirmation if suitable.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in his letter of appointment While you are on probation or trial, your suitability for permanent employment will be considered. If during the period of probation you are considered unsuitable for employment, you -

facts.text: In February 1951, Dr. Banerjee given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: In February 1951 Dr. Banerjee was given an increment of Rs. 5 per mensem, but on April 21, Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate,

facts.text: On April 21, 1951, Mr. Booth, manager, terminated Dr. Banerjee's services effective April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice.

anchor.surface_text: but on April 21, Dr. Banerjee received a letter from one Mr. Booth, manager of the tea estate, in which it was stated It has been found necessary to terminate your services with effect from the 22nd instant.

facts.text: No reasons given in termination notice; Dr. Banerjee inquired.

anchor.surface_text: You will of course receive one months salary in lieu of notice. As no reasons were given in the notice of termination, Dr. Banerjee wrote to the manager to find out why his services were being terminated.

facts.text: Manager replied reasons on medical side, deceitful manner adding figures to medical indent after signed by Dr. Cox.

anchor.surface_text: To this Dr. Banerjee received a reply to this effect The reasons for your discharge are on the medical side, which are outside my jurisdiction, best known to Dr. Cox but a main reason is because of the deceitful manner

facts.text: Manager stated Dr. Banerjee discharged for incompetence in medical duties, lack of knowledge in microscopical/lab work, faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock causing severe illness nearly paralysis.

anchor.surface_text: the manager wrote back to say that Dr.- K. P. Banerjee was discharged on the ground of incompetence in his medical duties and the chief medical officer Dr. Cox had found that Dr. Banerjee was incompetent

facts.text: Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha espoused Dr. Banerjee's cause and inquired reasons.

anchor.surface_text: in which you added figures to the requirements of the last medical indent after it had been signed by Dr, Cox, evidence of which is in my hands. The cause of Dr. Banerjee was then espoused

facts.text: Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination.

anchor.surface_text: and did not have sufficient knowledge of simple everyday microscopical and laboratory work which befalls the lot of every assistant medical officer in tea garden practice.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Banerjee being not a workman, his case is not one of an industrial dispute under the Industrial Disputes Act and his case is therefore beyond the jurisdiction of this Tribunal

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on March 14, 1956 limited to whether dispute re person not workman falls within s.2(k) definition.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an appeal to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Calcutta. That Tribunal affirmed the finding of Mr. Gohain to the effect that Dr. Banerjee was not a workman

facts.text: Supreme Court held dispute regarding termination of Dr. Banerjee's service not an industrial dispute under s.2(k), appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: the dispute regarding his termination of service was an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 k of the Act. The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

issues.text: the true scope and effect of the definition clause in s. 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: K. DAS J.-This appeal by special leave raises a question of some nicety and of considerable importance in the matter of industrial relations in this country. The question is the true scope and effect of the definition clause in s. 2 k of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 hereinafter referred

holdings.text: The expression 'any person' in section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 must be read subject to the limitations arising from the context, scheme and objects of the Act: (1) the dispute must be a real dispute capable of settlement or adjudication; (2) the parties to the dispute must have a direct or substantial interest in the employment or non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour of that person.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.2(k) with overall scheme of Act (ss.18,33,36), avoidance of absurd consequences (e.g., dispute over District Magistrate's salary), endorsement of precedents (Chagla CJ in Narendra Kumar Sen, Full Bench LAT), distinction from Western India Automobile (different facts re discharged workmen).

holdings.text: A dispute between employer and workmen regarding the termination of service of a person who is not a workman falls within s.2(k) only if the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest or community of interest in such person's employment or non-employment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Derives from textual analysis limited by context, scheme (binding on future workmen s.18, representation s.36), policy (no benefit to non-workmen categories), synthesis of precedents requiring community interest.

holdings.text: Dr. K.P. Banerjee was not a workman within the meaning of s.2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (as applicable pre-1956 amendments).

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from what has been stated above that the question whether Dr. K. P. Banerjee is or is not a workman within the meaning of the Act is no longer open to the parties and we must proceed on the footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of concurrent findings of lower tribunals (Tribunal and LAT); special leave limited excluding challenge to this finding.

holdings.text: The dispute regarding termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee's services is not an industrial dispute under s.2(k) as the workmen had no direct or substantial interest in his employment or non-employment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of direct/substantial interest test to facts: Dr. Banerjee medical/technical staff (different category), no community interest despite union membership claim.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed; no order as to costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of holding that no industrial dispute, hence tribunals lacked jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The four limitations proposed by appellants' counsel on 'any person' are incorrect; limitation 3 too wide (any employee), limitation 4 too general (personal interest or labour welfare).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis shows ignores distinction between workmen/non-workmen; replaces with community interest test.

anchor.surface_text: The absurd results that will follow such an interpretation have been forcefully expressed by Chagla C. J., in his decision in Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes  Labour Appellate  Tribunal  1  If any person were to be read as an expression without any limitation and qualification whatsoever, then we must number put even any territorial restriction on that expression.

precedents.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: Absurd results follow if 'any person' is read without limitation, including no territorial restriction on disputes over terms of employment anywhere in the world
precedents.cited_holding: If any person were to be read as an expression without any limitation and qualification whatsoever, then we must not put even any territorial restriction on that expression.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, it is only the aggrieved party who can raise a dispute but an industrial dispute is put on a collective basis, because it is not settled that an individual dispute, not espoused by others of the class to which the aggrieved party may belong, is not an industrial dispute within the meaning of s. 2 (k). As Isaacs J. observed in the Australian case of George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union 1  The very nature of, an industrial dispute as distinguished from an individual dispute, is to obtain new industrial conditions, not merely for the specific individuals then working from the specific individuals then employing them,

precedents.case_name: George Hudson Ltd. v. Australian Timber Workers Union
precedents.cited_proposition: Nature of industrial dispute is collective, for the class of employees from the class of employers
precedents.cited_holding: The very nature of an industrial dispute as distinguished from an individual dispute, is to obtain new industrial conditions, not merely for the specific individuals then working from the specific individuals then employing them, and not for the moment only, but for the class of employees from the class of employers

anchor.surface_text: The interpretation of s. 2 (k) of the Act has been the subject of consideration in various Indian decisions from different points of view. Two recent decisions of this Court considered the question if an individual dispute of a workman was within the definition of an industrial dispute. The decision in C. P. Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath 1 , related to the C. P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act (No. XXIII of 1947) and the decision in Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U. P. 2 , to the U. P.

precedents.case_name: C. P. Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath
precedents.cited_proposition: Individual dispute of a workman within definition of industrial dispute

anchor.surface_text: The decision in C. P. Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath 1 , related to the C. P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act (No. XXIII of 1947) and the decision in Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U. P. 2 , to the U. P. Industrial Disputes Act (No. XXVIII of 1947). Both these decisions considered s. 2 (k) of the Act, but with reference to a different problem.

precedents.case_name: Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U. P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Individual dispute of a workman within definition of industrial dispute

anchor.surface_text: The definition clause in s. 2 (k) was considered at some length by the Federal Court in Western India Automobile Association v. The Industrial Tribunal, Bombay 3 , and learned counsel for the appellants has placed great reliance on some of the observations made therein. The question which fell for decision in that case was whether industrial dispute included within its ambit a dispute with regard to reinstatement of certain dismissed workmen.

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. The Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: 'Non-employment' includes disputes regarding reinstatement of dismissed employees
precedents.cited_holding: Re-instatement is connected with non-employment and is therefore within the words of the definition. The non-employment of any person can amount to an industrial dispute between the employer and the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: A reference was also made to the decision of this Court in D. N. Banerji v. P. R. Mukherjee 1 . The question there was whether the expression industrial dispute included disputes between municipalities and their employees in branches of work analogous to the carrying on of a trade or business. More in point is the decision of the Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in a number of appeals reported in 1952 Labour Appeal Cases, p. 198,

precedents.case_name: D. N. Banerji v. P. R. Mukherjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Whether industrial dispute includes disputes between municipalities and their employees

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to state here that earlier a contrary view had been taken by the Calcutta High Court in Birla Brothers, Ltd. v. Modak 1 , by Banerjee J. in The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 2 , and by the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen 3 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Contrary view that 'any person' has wide meaning

anchor.surface_text: earlier a contrary view had been taken by the Calcutta High Court in Birla Brothers, Ltd. v. Modak 1 , by Banerjee J. in The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 2 , and by the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen 3 . It is necessary to emphasise here two considerations which have generally weighed with some of the learned Judges in support of the view expressed by them

precedents.case_name: The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak
precedents.cited_proposition: Contrary view that 'any person' means whatever individual is chosen, no restriction
precedents.cited_holding: Any person means whatever individual is chosen. I see no reason to restrict the meaning of the word Person.

anchor.surface_text: by Banerjee J. in The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 2 , and by the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, in East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen 3 . It is necessary to emphasise here two considerations which have generally weighed with some of the learned Judges in support of the view expressed by them these two Considerations are that (1) normally workmen will not raise a dispute in which they are not directly or substantially interested and (2) Government will not make a reference unless the dispute is a real or substantial one.

precedents.case_name: East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Contrary view supporting wide interpretation of 'any person'

anchor.surface_text: Two other later decisions have also been brought to our notice Prahlad Rai Oil Mills v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1 in which Bhargava J. expressed the view that the expression any person in the definition clause did not mean a workman and the decision in Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal 2 , being the decision of Chagla C. J. and Shah J. from which we have already quoted some extracts.

precedents.case_name: Prahlad Rai Oil Mills v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: 'Any person' in the definition clause did not mean a workman

anchor.surface_text: Prahlad Rai Oil Mills v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1 in which Bhargava J. expressed the view that the expression any person in the definition clause did number mean a workman and the decision in Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes  Labour Appellate  Tribunal 2 , being the decision of Chagla C. J. and Shah J. from which we have already quoted some extracts. An examination of the decisions referred to above undoubtedly discloses a divergence of opinion

precedents.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: Narrow interpretation of 'any person' based on context

anchor.surface_text: This was the view taken in United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Kedar Nath Gupta 1 . I will assume all this. It may also be true that the Act is not much concerned with employees other than workmen. But I am unable to see that all this is any reason for holding that the words any person must mean a person of the workman class.

precedents.case_name: United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. Kedar Nath Gupta
precedents.cited_proposition: Act makes distinction between workmen and other employees, focus on workmen

anchor.surface_text: In Birla Brothers Ltd. v. Modak 1 and in Western India Automobile Association v. -Industrial -Tribunal of Bombay 2 it was held that the words any person were not meant to refer only to workmen as defined in the Act but were wide and general and would include others who were not such workmen.

precedents.cited_proposition: Words 'any person' wide and include non-workmen
precedents.cited_holding: It cannot be argued that workmen dismissed prior to the Act are not persons.

anchor.surface_text: In Birla Brothers Ltd. v. Modak 1 and in Western India Automobile Association v. -Industrial -Tribunal of Bombay 2 it was held that the words any person were not meant to refer only to workmen as defined in the Act but were wide and general and would include others who were not such workmen.

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Words 'any person' wide enough for discharged workmen
precedents.cited_holding: The non-employment of any person can amount to an industrial dispute between the employer and the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: In The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak 3 , Banerjee J. said, Any person means whatever individual is chosen. I see no reason to restrict the meaning of the word Person. The same view was expressed in East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen 4 , which was the decision of an Industrial Tribunal.

precedents.case_name: The Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S. N. Modak
precedents.cited_proposition: 'Any person' means whatever individual, no restriction
precedents.cited_holding: Any person means whatever individual is chosen. I see no reason to restrict the meaning of the word Person.

anchor.surface_text: The same view was expressed in East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen 4 , which was the decision of an Industrial Tribunal. There is then some support for the view that the words any person should have no restriction put upon them.

precedents.case_name: East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and is dismissed. In the circumstances of this case there will be no order for costs.

It is clear from what has been stated above that the question whether Dr. K. P. Banerjee is or is not a workman within the meaning of the Act is no longer open to the parties and we must proceed on the footing that Dr. K. P. Banerjee was not a workman
